segment.target: Device Guard certification and compliance (Windows 10)

segment.source: Device Guard is a combination of hardware and software security features that, when configured together, will lock a device down so that it can only run trusted applications.
segment.target: Device Guard is a combination of hardware and software security features that, when configured together, will lock a device down so that it can only run trusted applications.

segment.source: Device Guard certification and compliance
segment.target: Device Guard certification and compliance

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Device Guard is a combination of hardware and software security features that, when configured together, will lock a device down so that it can only run trusted applications.
segment.target: Device Guard is a combination of hardware and software security features that, when configured together, will lock a device down so that it can only run trusted applications.

segment.source: If the app isn’t trusted it can’t run, period.
segment.target: If the app isn’t trusted it can’t run, period.

segment.source: It also means that even if an attacker manages to get control of the Windows kernel, he or she will be much less likely to be able to run malicious executable code after the computer restarts because of how decisions are made about what can run and when.
segment.target: It also means that even if an attacker manages to get control of the Windows kernel, he or she will be much less likely to be able to run malicious executable code after the computer restarts because of how decisions are made about what can run and when.

segment.source: Device Guard uses the new virtualization-based security in Windows 10 to isolate the Code Integrity service from the Windows kernel itself, letting the service use signatures defined by your enterprise-controlled policy to help determine what is trustworthy.
segment.target: Device Guard uses the new virtualization-based security in Windows 10 to isolate the Code Integrity service from the Windows kernel itself, letting the service use signatures defined by your enterprise-controlled policy to help determine what is trustworthy.

segment.source: In effect, the Code Integrity service runs alongside the kernel in a Windows hypervisor-protected container.
segment.target: In effect, the Code Integrity service runs alongside the kernel in a Windows hypervisor-protected container.

segment.source: For details on how to implement Device Guard, see Device Guard deployment guide.
segment.target: For details on how to implement Device Guard, see Device Guard deployment guide.

segment.source: Why use Device Guard
segment.target: Why use Device Guard

segment.source: With thousands of new malicious files created every day, using traditional methods like signature-based detection to fight against malware provides an inadequate defense against new attacks.
segment.target: With thousands of new malicious files created every day, using traditional methods like signature-based detection to fight against malware provides an inadequate defense against new attacks.

segment.source: Device Guard on Windows 10 changes from a mode where apps are trusted unless blocked by an antivirus or other security solutions, to a mode where the operating system trusts only apps authorized by your enterprise.
segment.target: Device Guard on Windows 10 changes from a mode where apps are trusted unless blocked by an antivirus or other security solutions, to a mode where the operating system trusts only apps authorized by your enterprise.

segment.source: Device Guard also helps protect against zero day attacks and works to combat the challenges of polymorphic viruses.
segment.target: Device Guard also helps protect against zero day attacks and works to combat the challenges of polymorphic viruses.

segment.source: Advantages to using Device Guard
segment.target: Advantages to using Device Guard

segment.source: You can take advantage of the benefits of Device Guard, based on what you turn on and use:
segment.target: You can take advantage of the benefits of Device Guard, based on what you turn on and use:

segment.target: Helps provide strong malware protection with enterprise manageability

segment.source: Helps provide the most advanced malware protection ever offered on the Windows platform
segment.target: Helps provide the most advanced malware protection ever offered on the Windows platform

segment.source: Offers improved tamper resistance
segment.target: Offers improved tamper resistance

segment.source: How Device Guard works
segment.target: How Device Guard works

segment.source: Device Guard restricts the Windows 10 operating system to only running code that’s signed by trusted signers, as defined by your Code Integrity policy through specific hardware and security configurations, including:
segment.target: Device Guard restricts the Windows 10 operating system to only running code that’s signed by trusted signers, as defined by your Code Integrity policy through specific hardware and security configurations, including:

segment.source: User Mode Code Integrity (UMCI)
segment.target: User Mode Code Integrity (UMCI)

segment.source: New kernel code integrity rules (including the new Windows Hardware Quality Labs (WHQL) signing constraints)
segment.target: New kernel code integrity rules (including the new Windows Hardware Quality Labs (WHQL) signing constraints)

segment.source: Secure Boot with database (db/dbx) restrictions
segment.target: Secure Boot with database (db/dbx) restrictions

segment.source: Virtualization-based security to help protect system memory and kernel mode apps and drivers from possible tampering.
segment.target: Virtualization-based security to help protect system memory and kernel mode apps and drivers from possible tampering.

segment.source: Optional: Trusted Platform Module (TPM) 1.2 or 2.0 Device Guard works with your image-building process, so you can turn the virtualization-based security feature on for capable devices, configure your Code Integrity policy, and set any other operating system settings you require for Windows 10.
segment.target: Optional: Trusted Platform Module (TPM) 1.2 or 2.0 Device Guard works with your image-building process, so you can turn the virtualization-based security feature on for capable devices, configure your Code Integrity policy, and set any other operating system settings you require for Windows 10.

segment.source: After that, Device Guard works to help protect your devices:
segment.target: After that, Device Guard works to help protect your devices:

segment.source: Your device starts up using Universal Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) Secure Boot, so that boot kits can’t run and so that Windows 10 starts before anything else.
segment.target: Your device starts up using Universal Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) Secure Boot, so that boot kits can’t run and so that Windows 10 starts before anything else.

segment.source: After securely starting up the Windows boot components, Windows 10 can start the Hyper-V virtualization-based security services, including Kernel Mode Code Integrity.
segment.target: After securely starting up the Windows boot components, Windows 10 can start the Hyper-V virtualization-based security services, including Kernel Mode Code Integrity.

segment.source: These services help protect the system core (kernel), privileged drivers, and system defenses, like anti-malware solutions, by preventing malware from running early in the boot process, or in kernel after startup.
segment.target: These services help protect the system core (kernel), privileged drivers, and system defenses, like anti-malware solutions, by preventing malware from running early in the boot process, or in kernel after startup.

segment.source: Device Guard uses UMCI to make sure that anything that runs in User mode, such as a service, a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, or a Classic Windows application is trusted, allowing only trusted binaries to run.
segment.target: Device Guard uses UMCI to make sure that anything that runs in User mode, such as a service, a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, or a Classic Windows application is trusted, allowing only trusted binaries to run.

segment.source: At the same time that Windows 10 starts up, so too does the trusted platform module (TPM).
segment.target: At the same time that Windows 10 starts up, so too does the trusted platform module (TPM).

segment.source: TPM provides an isolated hardware component that helps protect sensitive information, such as user credentials and certificates.
segment.target: TPM provides an isolated hardware component that helps protect sensitive information, such as user credentials and certificates.

segment.source: Windows 10 Enterprise
segment.target: Windows 10 Enterprise

segment.source: The PC must be running Windows 10 Enterprise.
segment.target: The PC must be running Windows 10 Enterprise.

segment.source: UEFI firmware version 2.3.1 or higher with UEFI Secure Boot and Platform Secure Boot
segment.target: UEFI firmware version 2.3.1 or higher with UEFI Secure Boot and Platform Secure Boot

segment.source: UEFI Secure Boot ensures that the device boots only authorized code.
segment.target: UEFI Secure Boot ensures that the device boots only authorized code.

segment.source: Additionally, Boot Integrity, also known as Platform Secure Boot must be supported.
segment.target: Additionally, Boot Integrity, also known as Platform Secure Boot must be supported.

segment.source: You can validate it against the following Windows Hardware Compatibility Program requirements:
segment.target: You can validate it against the following Windows Hardware Compatibility Program requirements:

segment.source: System.Fundamentals.Firmware.UEFISecureBoot
segment.target: System.Fundamentals.Firmware.UEFISecureBoot

segment.source: System.Fundamentals.Firmware.CS.UEFISecureBoot.ConnectedStandby
segment.target: System.Fundamentals.Firmware.CS.UEFISecureBoot.ConnectedStandby

segment.target: Virtualization extensions

segment.target: Second Level Address Translation

segment.source: Firmware lock
segment.target: Firmware lock

segment.source: The firmware setup should be locked to prevent other operating systems from starting and to prevent changes to the UEFI settings.
segment.target: The firmware setup should be locked to prevent other operating systems from starting and to prevent changes to the UEFI settings.

segment.source: Work with your hardware manufacturer to ensure that the devices are Device Guard ready
segment.target: Work with your hardware manufacturer to ensure that the devices are Device Guard ready

segment.source: You should require a firmware password or higher authentication to change firmware settings.
segment.target: You should require a firmware password or higher authentication to change firmware settings.

segment.source: x64 architecture
segment.target: x64 architecture

segment.source: The features that virtualization-based security uses in the Windows hypervisor can only run on a 64-bit PC.
segment.target: The features that virtualization-based security uses in the Windows hypervisor can only run on a 64-bit PC.

segment.source: A VT-d or AMD-Vi IOMMU (Input/output memory management unit)
segment.target: A VT-d or AMD-Vi IOMMU (Input/output memory management unit)

segment.source: In Windows 10, an IOMMU enhances system resiliency against memory attacks.
segment.target: In Windows 10, an IOMMU enhances system resiliency against memory attacks.
